I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan of 
up to $228,000,000 to Gulf SRC Company Limited (Gulf SRC) for the Chonburi Natural Gas 
Power Project in Thailand. 
 
2.  The project entails the construction and operation of a 2,500-megawatt (MW) combined-
cycle power plant in the WHA Eastern Seaboard Industrial Estate 1 (WHA Industrial Estate)1 of 
Chonburi  Province.  The  project  will  provide  significant  generating  capacity  that  is  reliable, 
efficient, and cost-effective. The project will be one of the largest power plants in Thailand and 
will  help  meet  the  projected  growth  and  industrial  transformation  plans  under  the  Eastern 
Economic Corridor (EEC) program. The project will utilize natural gas and will be the first to 
employ a new high-efficiency technology that reduces pollutants and emissions, providing cleaner 
air quality and lower carbon footprint.  
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
 
A.  Project Identification and Description 
 
3.  Project identification. With the intention of reaching high-income country status by 2032, 
Thailand launched “Thailand 4.0”, a development model that aims to pull the country out of the 
middle-income trap by creating a value-based economy driven by innovation. To put Thailand 4.0 
into action, the Government of Thailand adopted the EEC program, which will be the prime 
economic growth driver for the country over the next 10 years, from 2018 to 2028.2 The EEC 
initiative builds on the successful Eastern Seaboard Development Program (ESDP), which was 
launched in 1982 and is credited with the country’s rapid industrial transformation. The ESDP 
established  major  industries  along  Thailand’s  eastern  seaboard  (e.g.,  petrochemicals, 
electronics, automotive, and parts) and also facilitated major investments in infrastructure such 
as ports, highways, power plants, water supply, and industrial estates. The region has since 
become a strong commercial and tourism destination, as well as a strategic hub, gateway, and 
economic corridor connecting markets in the Greater Mekong Subregion.3 
 
4.  During the first 20 years, the ESDP contributed remarkable annual growth rates in export 
values (12%), industrial sector expansion (12%), and gross domestic product (7%). The national 
poverty  level  declined  substantially  from  67%  in  1986  to  under  9%  by  2016.  After  this 
unprecedented development, Thailand’s economy began to stagnate at middle-income levels, 
failing to graduate to the ranks of high-income countries. Building on the success of the ESDP, 
the government aims to promote the next generation of industries and infrastructure through its 
flagship EEC program. This includes mega public–private partnership projects centered on 
transport and logistics, e.g., international airport expansion (U-Tapao), deep sea port expansion 
(Map Ta Phut and Laem Chabang), the country’s first high-speed train, and other investments in 
industry, tourism, hospitals, and smart cities.4 In the first 5 years, combined public and private 
                                                
1  Formerly known as the Hemaraj Eastern Seaboard Estate. 
2  The EEC program will be implemented across an area of more than 13,000 square kilometers in the three eastern 
provinces of Chachoengsao, Chonburi, and Rayong. 
3  The eastern seaboard is part of the Greater Mekong Subregion Southern Economic Corridor that connects Bangkok, 
Phnom Penh, and Ho Chi Minh. 
4  The EEC program aims to promote 10 industry clusters: (i) next-generation automotive, (ii) intelligent electronics, (iii) 
advanced agriculture and biotechnology, (iv) food processing, (v) tourism, (vi) advanced robotics, (vii) integrated 
aviation, (viii) medical hub and comprehensive health care services, (ix) biofuels and biochemical, and (x) digital 
technology.

2 
investment is estimated to total B1.5 trillion ($43 billion) and the EEC initiative is expected to 
achieve economic growth of 5.0%, create more than 100,000 jobs, and attract 10 million more 
tourists on an annual basis. 
 
5.  To support the EEC program, sustain economic growth, and improve the standard of 
living, substantial investment is needed in social and utility services such as schools, hospitals, 
water, and electricity. Accordingly, Thailand’s 12th National Economic and Social Development 
Plan 2017–2021 calls for upgrading the economic, social, and environmental infrastructure and 
expanding public utility services on the eastern seaboard. Demand for electricity is expected to 
increase in parallel with growth in tourism, commercial, and industrial activity, and from the influx 
of residents in search of new employment and better quality of life. 
 
6.  The Chonburi Natural Gas Power Project will be centrally located in the EEC and will be 
the fourth-largest power plant and the largest combined-cycle power plant in the country. The 
project will become fully operational by 2022 as the government’s mega infrastructure projects 
under the EEC program come to fruition between 2021 and 2025. The timing also coincides with 
the largest decommissioning of aging power plants in Thailand, with more than 8,500 MW retiring 
between 2020 and 2025 (equivalent to 20% of the current national capacity).

7.  After the discovery of large reserves in the late 1970s, natural gas from the Gulf of 
Thailand provided the eastern seaboard with an abundant, low-cost, and secure source of energy 
and was an integral factor in fueling Thailand’s successful industrial transformation into a major 
export-orientated  economy.  The  eastern  seaboard  will  continue  to  use  natural  gas  as  the 
preferred choice of fuel because it emits substantially less greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions, 
dust, and ash than coal-fired power plants, the main alternative fuel choice for industrial parks on 
the eastern seaboard. But as reserves from the Gulf of Thailand are dwindling, the country has 
begun to rely more on liquefied natural gas (LNG) imports to meet its demand for natural gas. 
LNG demand is forecast to increase to 35 million tons per annum (MTPA) by 2036. PTT has 
already completed two terminals on the eastern seaboard with 10 MTPA of capacity, and a 1.5 
MPTA expansion is under construction. A third LNG terminal with 7.5 MTPA was approved and 
is due for completion in 2022. Greater reliance on LNG will make it necessary to procure the most 
efficient gas turbine technology to help contain the costs to end users. 
 
8.  The project is being developed under Thailand’s IPP program, which allows the private 
sector to build, own, and operate power projects with generating capacity of more than 90 MW. 
The IPP program was established in 1994 to promote efficient procurement and foster competition 
with an aim to minimize the government’s capital burden and lower the cost of electricity to end 
consumers. IPP contracts are awarded through a competitive bidding process based on the 
lowest levelized electricity price. Since its inception, the program has successfully tendered three 
IPP bidding rounds and awarded 13 contracts totaling more than 16,000 MW. The Chonburi 
Natural Gas Power Project was competitively awarded in the latest IPP bidding round, which was 
concluded in 2013. 
  
9.  Project design. The project entails the construction and operation of a 2,500 MW CCGT 
power plant in the WHA Industrial Estate of Chonburi Province, about 140 kilometers (km) east 
of Bangkok. The project is being developed under Thailand’s independent power producer (IPP) 
program and will be implemented under a 25-year power purchase agreement (PPA) with the 
Electricity Generating Authority of Thailand (EGAT) and a 25-year gas sales agreement (GSA) 
with PTT Public Company Limited (PTT).

3 
 
CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED  
 
10.  Borrower and sponsors. Gulf SRC, the borrower, was established in 2012 to develop, 
construct, own, and operate the project. The project sponsors are Gulf Energy Development 
Public Company Limited (GED), one of the largest power generation companies in Thailand, and 
Mitsui & Co., Ltd. (Mitsui) one of the largest trading companies in Japan. Gulf SRC is 100% owned 
by Independent Power Development, a joint venture between GED with 70% and Mitsui with 30% 
of the shares. 
 
11.  GED is a leading power generation company with the largest portfolio of contracted PPAs 
in Thailand. It has primarily focused on developing gas-fired power plants in Thailand under the 
IPP and small power producer programs. Currently, it has a portfolio of 23 gas-fired power projects 
with a total capacity of 11,100 MW (equity capacity of 6,303 MW). Of the 23 gas-fired projects, 15 
are operational, 7 are under construction (including the project), and 1 is under development. 
GED was listed on the Stock Exchange of Thailand in December 2017, and as of 14 September 
2018 has a market capitalization of about $4.5 billion. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
participated in GED’s initial public offering as a cornerstone investor with a 3% equity stake.5 
 
12.  Mitsui was established in 1947 as a general trading company and has since evolved into 
a diversified multinational. It is now one of Japan’s largest trading companies. It has a proven 
track record in developing more than 70 power projects in 21 countries. Its gross power generation 
capacity totals 35 gigawatts, its net equity capacity 9.6 gigawatts. Mitsui has particular expertise 
in gas-fired power generation—such projects account for more than half of its total equity capacity. 
It is rated A by S&P, A3 by Moody’s, and AA- by Rating & Investment Inc. 
 
13.  Integrity due diligence and enhanced tax integrity due diligence were conducted by ADB.6 
No significant issues were identified, and the results of the tax integrity analysis is set out in the 
tax integrity disclosure document.7 
 
B.  Development Impact, Outcome, and Outputs 
 
14.  Impact. The project is aligned with the following impact: power system stability and 
reliability ensured.8 
 
Outcome. The project will have the following outcome: increased delivery of stable and reliable 
power to the domestic grid.

C.  Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations 
 
16.  Consistency with ADB strategy and country strategy. The project is consistent with 
ADB’s Strategy 2030,9 which calls for (i) promoting private sector participation in infrastructure 
through project financing, (ii) prioritizing investments in low GHG emission energy, (iii) building 
strong partnerships for more resource mobilization, and (iv) accelerating progress in gender 
equity. ADB’s support for the project is also in line with its country partnership strategy, 2013–
2016 for Thailand,10 and its country operations business plan, 2018–2020,11 both of which 
promote the support for private sector development, energy infrastructure, and responding to 
Thailand’s needs and priorities as an upper middle-income country. 
 
17.  Consistency with sector strategy and associated ADB operations. The project is 
consistent with ADB’s Energy Policy,12 which emphasizes investments in energy efficiency, least-
cost supply, and private sector participation. ADB supports projects that use efficient technologies 
such as CCGT or incorporate state-of-the-art emission control equipment. 
 
18.  Lessons from previous operations. The project follows ADB’s prior financing of two IPP 
projects in Thailand, the Nong-Saeng Natural Gas Power Project (2011) and the Ayudhaya 
Natural Gas Power Project (2012). ADB provided long-term debt financing to the projects—the 
first project financing arrangements in Thailand with loan tenures of 23 years.

III.  THE PROPOSED ADB ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  The Assistance 
 
20.  ADB will provide a proposed limited-recourse project-finance loan of up to $228 million 
from ADB’s ordinary capital resources. ADB’s loan will have a tenor of 23 years and includes a 4-
year grace period during construction and commissioning. A consortium of financial institutions—
including the Japan Bank for International Cooperation, the Export-Import Bank of Thailand, and 
nine commercial banks—will participate in parallel to ADB with the same loan tenor. 
 
B.  Value Added by ADB Assistance 
 
21.  The financing needs of the project are substantial, requiring about $1.15 billion of long-
term, limited-recourse debt. ADB’s assistance is catalyzing $923 million or about $4 of cofinancing

6 
for  every  $1  of  ADB  assistance.  ADB  has  been  engaged  in  the  financial  structuring  and 
safeguards review from early stage and its role as an anchor lender provides credibility to the 
project and its developers to help attract other financial institutions to participate. ADB’s proactive 
role early on in the process was critical for garnering interest from local and international financial 
institutions during the bank solicitation process and helps enable the successful financial closing. 
ADB also endorses the project’s use of the most advanced technology in terms of high-efficiency 
and low-carbon, which has a maximum rated efficiency greater than 63%. The project will be the 
first  commercial  deployment  of  MHPS’s  most  advanced  and  efficient  turbine,  and  such 
endorsement from ADB and subsequent demonstration effect will lead to faster adoption from 
other developers and reduce the perceived risk by other financial institutions. 
 
22.  ADB also plays a lead role in the due diligence process, especially with respect to 
environmental,  social,  gender,  and  integrity  standards,  as  well  as  in  the  negotiations  and 
structuring  of  the  transaction.  With  ADB’s  guidance,  the  project  will  adopt  more  stringent 
safeguard measures than what is required under national standards and incorporate certain 
gender-inducive elements in the project design, such as employment targets for women and 
community outreach campaigns.

IV.  POLICY COMPLIANCE 
 
A.  Safeguards and Social Dimensions 
 
23.  ADB  has  categorized  the  investment  in  compliance  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy 
Statement (2009) as follows: environment (category A), involuntary resettlement (category B), 
and indigenous peoples (category C).14 A draft environmental and social impact assessment 
(ESIA) and management plans were prepared by Gulf SRC and disclosed on ADB’s website.15 
The ESIA recorded no presence of distinct and vulnerable indigenous peoples or ethnic minority 
groups in the project’s area of influence. 
 
24.  ADB undertook due diligence and reviewed the project’s potential environmental and 
social impacts and the measures to avoid, minimize, mitigate, and compensate for the adverse 
impacts in the safeguard reports and plans. The ESIA was updated to meet ADB’s requirements, 
and ADB is working with the sponsors to ensure compliance with its Safeguard Policy Statement, 
and applicable policies and guidelines, and finalize the ESIA prior to the ADB Board of Directors 
approval. 16  The  environmental  and  social  measures  and  the  institutional  capacity  and 
commitment of Gulf SRC to manage the project’s social and environmental impacts are deemed 
adequate. 
 
25.  Environment (category A). Key construction phase impacts will include temporary noise, 
dust, traffic, solid and liquid waste generation, hazardous substances, and occupational and 
public health and safety issues. During operation, key potential impacts include air and noise

emissions, and effluent discharges. The ESIA management plans will avoid, minimize, and 
mitigate expected impacts and risks.17 The updated draft ESIA confirmed that a stack height of 
60 meters will result in better ground-level concentration values than a stack height of 65.68 
meters. Stack emissions will comply with applicable guidelines and national standards.  Air 
dispersion modeling confirmed that national ambient air quality standards will be met,18 and the 
project will not contribute more than 25% of the national air quality standard at sensitive receptor 
locations. 19 GHG emissions are estimated to be 8.59 million tons of carbon dioxide per year when 
using natural gas, 20 and GHG monitoring will be undertaken. The noise calculation results for 
construction and operation indicated that noise levels will be elevated by less than 3 A-weighted 
decibels at nearest sensitive receptors if the proposed temporary and permanent noise barriers 
are installed. The updated ESIA confirmed that effluent discharges will not have significant 
impacts on the receiving waters. 
 
26.  Rounds of public consultation were undertaken in Chonburi and Rayong provinces in July–
August 2014, May 2015, and April 2018. Public concerns and feedback from sponsors from the 
first and second rounds of consultations are discussed in the disclosed draft ESIA, and the 
updated ESIA incorporates the results of the 2018 consultations. 
 
27.  Involuntary resettlement (category B). The ESIA and ADB due diligence found no 
legacy issues regarding historical transfer of project land to the WHA Industrial Estate and then 
on to the project. Acquisition of predominantly agricultural land for construction of the associated 
transmission line will be undertaken by EGAT following national law, and according to the project 
ESIA is expected to cause non-major involuntary economic displacement impacts. Gulf SRC will 
monitor EGAT’s land acquisition process and prepare, as part of the ESMP package, a land 
acquisition and compensation plan to ensure that the livelihoods of affected people are restored 
to  pre-project  levels  or  better.  ADB  will  disclose  the  plan  once  prepared  and  monitor  its 
implementation. 
 
28.  Gender and other social aspects. The project has included some gender elements to 
enhance benefits to women beyond gender equality measures stipulated under national law and 
ADB safeguard requirements—e.g., equal opportunity in employment, nondiscrimination in the 
workplace, and prevention of sexual violence, harassment of local communities, and disease 
transmission. It committed to giving women 15% of the additional jobs required for plant operation. 
Such a commitment is untypical for power plants, where the physical nature of the work usually 
limits women’s share of jobs to 5%–10%. Gulf SRC will also undertake community outreach 
activities for girls on health as well as technical skills training.21 
 
29.  Gulf SRC will comply with national labor laws and, pursuant to ADB’s Social Protection 
Strategy (2001), will take measures to comply with the internationally recognized core labor 
standards.22 The client will report regularly to ADB on (i) its and its contractors’ compliance with

B.  Anticorruption Policy 
 
30.  Gulf SRC was advised of ADB’s policy of implementing best international practice relating 
to combating corruption, money laundering, and the financing of terrorism. ADB will ensure that 
the investment documentation includes appropriate provisions prohibiting corruption, money 
laundering, and the financing of terrorism; and remedies for ADB in the event of noncompliance. 
 
C.  Investment Limitations 
 
31.  The  proposed  loan  is  within  the  medium-term,  country,  industry,  group,  and  single 
exposure limits for nonsovereign investments as stipulated by the Board. 
 
D.  Assurances 
 
32.  Consistent with the Agreement Establishing the Asian Development Bank (the Charter),24 
ADB  will proceed with the proposed assistance upon establishing that  the Government of 
Thailand has no objection to the proposed assistance to Gulf SRC. ADB will enter into suitable 
finance documentation, in form and substance satisfactory to ADB, following approval of the 
proposed assistance by the ADB Board of Directors. 
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
33.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the loan of up to 
$228,000,000 from ADB’s ordinary capital resources to Gulf SRC Company Limited for the 
Chonburi  Natural  Gas  Power  Project  in  Thailand,  with  such  terms  and  conditions  as  are 
substantially in accordance with those set forth in this report, and as may be reported to the Board.

metadata.Subject: The project entails the construction and operation of a 2,500-megawatt (MW) combined cycle power plant in the WHA Eastern Seaboard Industrial Estate of Chonburi Province. It will be one of the largest power plants in Thailand and will be the first to employ a new high-efficiency technology that reduces pollutants and emissions, providing cleaner air quality and lower carbon footprint.
